title: Sidekick of a Superstar - Chapter 47 Philly
body:
This chapter is short, because the concerts are basically day by day and it’s hard to write the same amount about three days and one day. I hope the story makes sense, I guess you feel something is happening and it’s gonna burst soon. 

Word count: 1.4k

There were three shows in three nights. It’s always exhausting which doesn’t help the tension that was between you and Harry. So you asked him to have a private breakfast that day. You were in his hotel room and just started eating when you brought it up.

“Harry, we still haven’t talked about some things, and I feel we need to.”

“I know.”

“I just want to say that those messages broke my heart every time I got them. They were absurd but still a little doubt was in me, a ‘What if?”

Silence.

“I love you with all my heart, but I’m insecure about some things.”

“I must admit I was thinking what if you really love Louis. More than you love me. And I was mad because he walked in and stole you with his charm and sadness that you must’ve helped.”

“I do love him, but not like I love you” you smiled.

“So it’s not weird that we’re still insecure?” he asked.

“No, but I want to do against it. Right now the schedule is so strict we can barely do anything besides work, but as soon as we will have a little more free time, we could work on it”

“Sounds like a plan” he smiled.

“Deal.”

“Deal.”

What you didn’t mention was that you didn’t like that Kacey is all the time with Harry. But this time the schedule was really strict and you wanted to focus on your work. You barely spent more time with Harry that day. After breakfast you all went to the venue and you started working in your dressing room. You opened Spotify and you saw that 5sos just released their new album. You listened to it whole day on repeat. But there was one song that you loved so much, because you always went back to that one. Lie to Me.

You were so into it when there was a knock on your door. Sarah and Clare came after.

“Hey!”

“We heard the music and came in” Sarah said.

“But we actually wanted to see you, girl” Clare added.

“Thanks”

“You look all sad recently so we want to cheer you up a bit” Sarah winked. They had a bottle of cider for the three of you. So you found yourself drinking and laughing with Sarah and Clare that afternoon. It was so much fun. You talked about a lot of things and tried to come up with some conspiracy theories and actually you found out that you were in Harry’s Gucci ad video last time, but you were under cover. You even had a search about all of you on the dark web of blogs. It was nice to see that mostly you all had your own fans and they loved and supported all of you. As a band and as individuals too. But soon a feeling hit you. You didn’t miss Harry at all. In the last few months, since you dated him, you always ached to be with him all the time. But now you were happy “alone” and didn’t even think about what he’s doing. It scared you. Adam dragged you out of your thoughts when he came in and said that they should do soundcheck but Sarah and Clare are missing. They went to soundcheck but you stayed and sat down a bit. Your clothes arrived soon and you put them on, realizing that it’s almost the same as Harry’s so you’re gonna be twinning again. You called Lottie and she was on speaker.

“Hi, darling!”

“Hello, old friend!”

“Old friend? You’re missing me, huh?”

“I haven’t seen you since May, what do you think?”

“Oh, Lottie darling, I miss you too.”

“Anyways, thank you to talk to Louis about me”

“Oh, God! I’m so sorry I forgot to and now he’s in London…” you said because you were sure she sarcastically thanked you.

“What are you talking about? Yesterday he called me and we’re having dinner tomorrow”

“What?”

“What what? He kind of asked me on a date”

“Wow, but I approve it” you smiled.

“Thanks! So you really haven’t talked to him?”

“No, I forgot.” you admitted.

“Then it’s genuine, I like it” she said.

“Look, I gotta go” you said when you saw Harry look into your room asking for permission to enter. “Love you”

“Love you too, give a hug to Harry for me”

“I will.” You hung up.

“We finished soundcheck, twin” he smiled.

“Great” you stood up and hugged him. “I don’t want to lose you, Harry”

“Why would you lose me, love?” he chuckled and tightened the hug.

“Dunno” you sighed. “I just don’t want to.”

“I miss you” he said. It would’ve been strange to hear, but you felt the same too. You were in each other’s company 24/7 but still felt like you’re not together. In body he was there, but you two didn’t connect most of the time. You felt that you’re on the way of healing, but you knew that another problem could tear this apart.

“Lottie sent a hug”

“Oh, I should call her, it was a while ago when we talked. How’s she?”

“She’s got a date” you smiled.

“Wow, do I know the guy?”

“Yes, you do” you smiled at him while he sat down. Harry frowned when he saw you smirk.

“Louis” you said and his eyes widened.

“What?”

“Yeah, I was surprised too. But Lottie loves him.”

“If he makes a wrong move…”  he said, being protective of his favourite pregnant woman.

“If she makes a wrong move…” you said, being protective of your friend. You laughed together.

A voice came on your walkie: “Five minutes before going to stage, Harry.”

“Why did he say Harry if I don’t have a walkie?”

“Well, I guess it’s so obvious that you’re with me” you said to him. “Copied” you said to the walkie.

“Let’s go, put on a show” you reached your hand for him to take it. He grabbed it and then pulled you into a side hug and that’s how you walked through the whole building. There was still a minute before he had to leave, his phone was with him and he sent a text to Lottie.

“Is it okay if I anonymously talk about you in front of an arena?”

“You can’t be anon, they’ve seen your face”

“You”

“DOn’t have to be anon, make me famous so I will get enough money to set up my own company”

“Take care mama bear”

The concert was great. Harry promised to sign a shoe of a fan and found a pregnant lady. He offered her a seat and started talking with her. It was all funny and you hid your face in your palms when he complimented her “Congratulations on having sex at least twice” and you were like “Oh God! I’m dating a comedian” But surprisingly he added some more stories.

“You know, I have a friend. She’s pregnant. I know you watch the live stream, darling even though it’s like early morning in London. Lottie, I just want you to know, that you’re gonna be an amazing mum and you have my back, whatever happens, we’ll help you through it. She’s lovely and the best barista in London” he winked. “She’s the only person who has the right to kick my arse anytime. I don’ tell her everyday, but she’s a good friend of mine and I’m happy I’ve got to know her through my uhm… best friend. So the next song…” you were in tears and Lottie was in tears too. She sent you a text: “Give an even bigger hug and a kiss to his face. I’m sobbing. I’ll call him later.”

It meant a lot to her because she was always doubting she’s gonna be a good mother and she can take care of a child. She needed it and you were amazed how much Harry cared about her. Before the concert ended you found the person Harry promised a sign for and took her out of the crowd by security. You walked her to Harry in his dressing room. They spent a few minutes together and then she left.

“Thank you for all your kind words to Lottie, she said she’s gonna call you later, but she was really emotional. I know it means a lot to her.”

“I know she needed that and I meant every word I said” he smiled.

“Yes, you do” you smiled at him while he sat down. Harry frowned when he saw you smirk.

“Louis” you said and his eyes widened.

“What?”

“Yeah, I was surprised too. But Lottie loves him.”

“If he makes a wrong move…”  he said, being protective of his favourite pregnant woman.

“If she makes a wrong move…” you said, being protective of your friend. You laughed together.

A voice came on your walkie: “Five minutes before going to stage, Harry.”

“Why did he say Harry if I don’t have a walkie?”

“Well, I guess it’s so obvious that you’re with me” you said to him. “Copied” you said to the walkie.

“Let’s go, put on a show” you reached your hand for him to take it. He grabbed it and then pulled you into a side hug and that’s how you walked through the whole building. There was still a minute before he had to leave, his phone was with him and he sent a text to Lottie.

“Is it okay if I anonymously talk about you in front of an arena?”

“You can’t be anon, they’ve seen your face”

“You”

“DOn’t have to be anon, make me famous so I will get enough money to set up my own company”

“Take care mama bear”

The concert was great. Harry promised to sign a shoe of a fan and found a pregnant lady. He offered her a seat and started talking with her. It was all funny and you hid your face in your palms when he complimented her “Congratulations on having sex at least twice” and you were like “Oh God! I’m dating a comedian” But surprisingly he added some more stories.

“You know, I have a friend. She’s pregnant. I know you watch the live stream, darling even though it’s like early morning in London. Lottie, I just want you to know, that you’re gonna be an amazing mum and you have my back, whatever happens, we’ll help you through it. She’s lovely and the best barista in London” he winked. “She’s the only person who has the right to kick my arse anytime. I don’ tell her everyday, but she’s a good friend of mine and I’m happy I’ve got to know her through my uhm… best friend. So the next song…” you were in tears and Lottie was in tears too. She sent you a text: “Give an even bigger hug and a kiss to his face. I’m sobbing. I’ll call him later.”

It meant a lot to her because she was always doubting she’s gonna be a good mother and she can take care of a child. She needed it and you were amazed how much Harry cared about her. Before the concert ended you found the person Harry promised a sign for and took her out of the crowd by security. You walked her to Harry in his dressing room. They spent a few minutes together and then she left.

“Thank you for all your kind words to Lottie, she said she’s gonna call you later, but she was really emotional. I know it means a lot to her.”

“I know she needed that and I meant every word I said” he smiled.

part two to wild card.

or

where harry’s having a hard time without y/n

thank you for all the love on wild card! this is extra™ but I love this part, it is my second child. another long read so save for later if you have to!

read part one here

—–

Never has there been a sight more desecrating to his heart than that of y/n slipping away from his fingertips.

He hears the gentle “Goodnight, Harry” that croaks from her before she disappears into the depths of her somber bedroom. He does not register the silence until it submerges the entire apartment. His ears strain to catch even the faintest sound on the other side of the door. The painted walls muffle her movements; not a single light shines from the crack at his feet.

The poor man is a blossoming flower; petals of sweetness expand from the force of nature’s love. He is powerful, but the dirt pulls him to the ground with its muddy hands, and steadies him for the hurricane that is to strike. He cannot move. He stands and relives the events that baffle his brain: she walks away; she dismisses him with a fragile goodnight, a farewell that he fears will be the last; he confesses his secrets and she scrambles with strange abandonment. Over a dozen times does he relive those taunting moments, seconds ticking further and further away.

This doesn’t make the least bit of sense to him. He can imagine it from his perspective without strife. He professes his love, and it unveils a grand twist to their years-long story. He can taste the sorrow on her lips, a mixture of salt and relief. He can feel the dip in her neck where his eager hands find a home, fingertips pressing with a passion. He can imagine her sweet lips to confess the eight letters that welcome heaven to his heart. When he opens his eyes, he stares at an empty wall instead. Her presence lingers, but she is not here. 

Harry doesn’t make a sound. He doesn’t know if she sleeps tenderly under the comfort of her sheets – if exhaustion makes it that much easier for her to rest. He does not pick apart his brain to imagine, because to imagine her all snug in his shaded arms is too much to bear. Consequently, with the last ounce of energy that he has left, he shakes the desire from his clouded mind, and walks away.

>Can you please call me back? 

>I’m sorry if I was pressuring you. It wasn’t my intention. 

>I leave on the sixth. Can we please talk before then?

Messages slither their way into Harry’s everyday routine. Unanswered calls are a given, and his desperate voicemails are almost therapeutic. His time ticks away, and it fills with him an anxiety that no crowd can ever compare with. In the days that follow, he succumbs to self-hatred. He will never forgive himself for ruining something so special. A fresh sheet once written with loving memories is nothing but a smudge of ink, a ball that he crumples with his own bare hands. The wrinkles and creases can never return to their former smooth state, eternally marking his selfish behavior in the folded lines.

Four days come and go. He goes longer periods of time without communicating with y/n, but this particular situation has his head spinning off and into the clouds. She has yet to call him back, and he will have to leave soon. His career requires his attention elsewhere, in places that y/n cannot go. Somewhere in his mind, he wonders if that is her plan. Does she count the days, waiting for him to disappear so that finally she can too?

“Why?” Harry asks her. His legs dangle, knees bent at the edge of the hotel bed. His body spreads across the center. One hand covers his face, index finger and thumb rubbing harshly against his eyes. The other clutches his phone, and presses it against his flaming ear. “Why aren’t you picking up your phone? You couldn’t have thrown it out the window again. Why can’t you just call me back or send me a message to fuck off? Why do you insist on being so—”

Harry stops himself. He considers the word on his tongue: annoying. She is being remarkably annoying, impossibly infuriating, a down-right burden. The worst part of it all is that she does nothing. She ignores him and continues to live her own separate life, and there really isn’t anything she can do to control how annoying she’s being. In spite of this, there is a beat that his heart reserves for only her.

“Just call me back. Please. Anything.”

By the time the sixth rolls around, Harry parallels a broken record of apologies and pleas. He considers, in a hopeful part of his mind, that it is her favorite one to play. She does not make any attempts to throw out the vinyl that screams with deep scratches, so she must enjoy the melody of his broken heart and dance in his misery. As cruel as it sounds, he prefers this over the possibility that she simply wishes to wear out the beloved composition until there is nothing left to let go of.

Chances are that this is why he has not sought out the most obvious of solutions. He knows the route to her apartment, he knows when she is absent and when she is at home. He even knows how to sneak his way in, and though it may be a psychotically drastic turn, it is such an easy game for him to play. The fifty-fifty gamble, however, is what keeps him from paying her the visit. Cornering her to make a decision – to love him back or to reject his heart once again – will give him a definite answer, and for once, uncertainty is his friend. He savors these one-sided conversations because then he can imagine her listening on the other end. It is better than to know for certain if she does not care for him or his heart. It is better to suffer through the fatal chase than to not feel the pain at all.

As he boards the plane, he keeps his heart open. As he settles into his private seat, he keeps her words with him. As he feels the runway disappear from beneath him, he holds his phone steady in his hands, and composes his final attempt before dreaming in the clouds. 

>I understand if you don’t want to talk to me

>but wherever I’ll be, I’ll still wait for your call.

 Months pass by, and Harry revolves around a vacant world. He visits countries that are rich with beauty. The roads are endless in their mystical magic. He passes strangers on his journeys, and they tell him of how happy he appears; how genuine his smile perceives. They don’t know that he has not spoken to y/n in months, and it affects his craft in both a negative and positive way. She does not consume him. He devotes his entirety to her, but his life goes on without her. He is capable of finding humor in small things, distracts himself with the whimsical wonders of the world, and spares no thought to the woman who spears his love. 

He is doing fine, and he enjoys himself frequently, but there comes a moment when everything stops. His brain peaks at an image of her: she walks away, and it strikes a hollow spark within. He laughs, he listens, he lives – at the end of the day, she is there, and the sullen moments of that night sneak up on him like a killer in the shadows.

Tonight, he celebrates. Despite his extravagant lifestyle, Harry prefers intimate get-togethers to explosive events. He’s not one to sell himself to the wealthiest festivities that shower him in praise and flaunt his name. He doesn’t need the exploitation, but tonight, he tries not to mind it. He steps into the empty elevator and listens to the doors close behind him as Jeff presses the button to the party’s floor. While his friend fixes his appearance last minute in the reflective surface of the elevator walls, Harry gazes at the number rising above his head.

“I’m not plannin’ on staying long,” he says, observing his own appearance in the reflection. It is nothing too lavishing for a company’s anniversary party, but it has enough flare to properly mark it as his own style.

“I’m there as long as you are,” Jeff responds. He releases his hands from the collar of his button-up. “Are you going to head back to your hotel room?”

“Maybe. Although I am in the mood for anything other than late-night television.” 

His friend laughs, nodding his head in agreement. “You’re the boss. But try to not get too crazy tonight, you still have emails to respond to the morning, and another meeting over Skype.”

Jeff goes on with his business talk, and Harry isn’t too sure about whether he’s grateful for this or not. It’s nice to indulge into a schedule for the next day, but it is also nice to not worry over the chaos of his career for one night. In the interim of their discussion, the elevator dings and pauses motion. When Harry looks up, he sees that there are still a few more floors to go, but the sparkling doors open, and the two friends give each other a look.

A man is the first to enter. He shines in a flamboyantly bold outfit, one that is sure to present him with the attention that he desires. He flashes a charming smile, presses his palms flat against the side of the doors, and tilts his head to shout over his shoulder. “Hurry your asses up or I’m going without you!”

The confident man moves himself into the back-right corner, with Harry and Jeff silent against the adjacent back wall. An exasperated “My god,” breathes out from the hallway, faint footsteps rush down the carpet floors. Harry takes a step forward, situating himself near the keypad with a finger pushing down on the button that keeps the doors open. While waiting for the next person to arrive, he takes a quick glance at the man in the corner and wonders where he has seen his face before.

“Sasha, you better be holding open the doors!” the woman yells, which causes the three men to chuckle with each other in time. Harry, however, settles down from the amusement fairly quickly as he peruses the familiar voice. He doesn’t ponder for long, because sooner than later, the mysterious woman appears by the doors and glares at her friend. She opens her plump lips as if to curse at him, but notices the other two entities and shifts her demeanor. “Oh, I’m sorry, I didn’t know—”

The woman pauses her sentence. She observes Harry and Jeff, who she comes to realize are not mere strangers hitching for a ride up. Harry feels his heart drop for a short moment, his finger falls from the sleek button. Her perfecting attire radiates with a dazzling energy amid the dull and hazy lights, and her smile is far brighter than Harry recalls last seeing.

“Hey!” she exclaims. She walks over the threshold, and takes a step closer to Harry with her arms outstretching for a hug. “It’s been a while.”

“Sophia,” Harry greets her. He allows her to pull him in for a reuniting embrace, patting her back in a gently and amiable manner. “Lovely to see you.”

Though his voice is monotone, he is honest with his words. It is a surprise to see Sophia on this strange night, but she has always been a delight to him and those around her. He begins to feel better about the crowd that this party will bring, but a startling notion twirls in the field of his flower-mind. Sophia pulls away, delivers a million-dollar smile, and strolls over to greet Jeff, who she is also an acquaintance of. The elevator doors begin to push together, and Harry lets out a sigh of relief for what he believes will be a smooth night from here on out.

“Wait! Sasha!” someone calls out from the hallway, their footsteps patter against the carpet floors. A manicured hand reaches out to the narrow space left between the closing doors. Harry’s eyes bulge out of his head, but he is quick to act upon the situation unlike the three mindless bystanders. He reaches out to wave his hand in front of the doors while simultaneously pushing the button that keeps them open. Sasha, on the other hand, stands unbothered in his corner, smart phone in hand. He looks up in time to see the doors opening once again, but fails to catch the incredulous gaze shared between two long-lost friends.

“Sorry,” Sasha mumbles, and returns to his device. 

Time ticks away, and the stare lingers on, but Harry feels the universe falter in its continuous lifetime. Having her in the flesh reminds him of his hopeless attempts, and in one frail second, their paths intersect for one painfully perfect moment. It scares him then of what she will do, and in this confined box with four other people, he wishes to be alone. One look at her eyes – once leaking in pain; one look at her cheeks – once staining in melancholy tears; one look at her and he remembers how it had felt to see her walk away.

Despite his fears, he does not anticipate a smile. An authentic smile reaching to her sparkling eyes that disguise behind layers of beauty products to accentuate her marvelous attire. Even so, there is no difference in how his eyes perceive her. Whether she is in a glamorous element or spilling her secrets through sobs, his entire heart belongs to her. His heart that fluctuates with emotions momentarily settles on just one. Before he can return the kind gesture, before he can exhale with content and glee, her arms pull him in by the shoulders. She wraps herself softly around his frame, and her scent is the most divine, but he can only bask in it for a second before associating it with the torture he knows all too well. 

“Hi, Harry,” she says, and faintly nuzzles her chin in the crook of his neck. “Haven’t heard from you in a while.”

Harry stiffens. Over her shoulder, he can see the doors closing for a final time. He can hear the other three in their own conversation. He can feel her warm breath sending twisters down his spine. It is over her shoulder that the color of the world shifts to gray. She has not heard from him in a while, but he calls her at least once every week. Try as he might, he cannot forget her, and so he reaches out with hope that every call will be the one she finally answers.

Her grip eases, though Harry’s arms have long fallen from her waist. She pulls away, and peers up at him with caution in her eyes. Her smile paints a completely different picture. “How’ve you been?” she asks, purses her lips. Her casual behavior makes him sad, and if he isn’t mistaken, she looks to be begging him to stay quiet; she’s begging him to not start something tonight that is unfinished from months ago.

“Fine,” he mumbles, but the answer carries more significance than he lets on. She goes to stand by Sasha, but he recalls his messages; he recalls how on her end, the decline button saves her. The option to mute his conversation is a gift. Clearing her voicemail box is lifting a weight that she had never wanted on her shoulders. Her solution is to pretend. She does as his first voicemail had asked her and pretends that the secret night of confessions had never happened. She somehow pushes that memory away and pretends that everything is fine in their broken friendship.

She pretends that his love does not exist, and that is the greatest pain of all. 

The ride up the remaining floors is uncomfortable for him, especially when he realizes that the trio are going to the same party that he is. Where Jeff mingles in a short conversation with Sophia and Sasha – who Harry now remembers seeing in one of y/n’s Instagram posts – the younger man stands in his isolation by the keypad. He starts to doubt that she is in love with him too. He wishes for her to spare him a glance; he wants to see the weakness in her frown. He cannot fathom how it is possible to stay away from the person that has one’s heart, or even act as though they barely exist. If he is to see that weakness, that pouty little expression, then he will know if she truly loves him too.

It feels like lifetimes before the elevator doors open to a floor that drowns in music. Sasha is the first of the trio to step out, sashaying as he opens up Snapchat on his phone with a single hand. Harry reminisces a time when his younger self had grown fond of Twitter. With a harsh push under the spotlight, he’s since then snapped out of the social network daze and has learned a great deal of restraint. It is that restraint that has kept him from checking up on y/n’s profiles in those lonely few months, but he wonders if he had taken the chance to peak, would he have known about her appearance tonight?

He laughs, he listens, he lives – at the end of the day, she is there, and the sullen moments of that night sneak up on him like a killer in the shadows.

An exasperated “My god,” breathes out from the hallway, faint footsteps rush down the carpet floors. Harry takes a step forward, situating himself near the keypad with a finger pushing down on the button that keeps the doors open. Harry feels his heart drop for a short moment, his finger falls from the sleek button. Her perfecting attire radiates with a dazzling energy amid the dull and hazy lights, and her smile is far brighter than Harry recalls last seeing.

If he is to see that weakness, that pouty little expression, then he will know if she truly loves him too.

Harry reminisces a time when his younger self had grown fond of Twitter. With a harsh push under the spotlight, he’s since then snapped out of the social network daze and has learned a great deal of restraint. It is that restraint that has kept him from checking up on y/n’s profiles in those lonely few months, but he wonders if he had taken the chance to peak, would he have known about her appearance tonight?

“Nice catching up, Jeff,” Sophia says. She links her arm with y/n’s, helping her friend out the elevator since she can’t find it within herself to look up. As they pass by Harry, Sophia turns her head and sends him a nod and a smirk, which is far more attention than y/n has given him in the past few months.

Harry smiles politely and allows the two women to scurry away before trailing far behind them. He steps out onto the floor, Jeff right on his tail, and the sea of beautiful faces begin to gawk at the legend before them. “Did you know that y/n would be here?” Harry asks, aware that the madness will soon mask his voice.

“No,” Jeff answers, but tilts his head at the question. “I figured between the two of us, you would have been the one to know.”

“Like she said,” Harry replies, “It’s been a while.” 

After the so-called falling out, Harry had refused to talk about it with anyone. It isn’t as if what had happened embarrasses him, or that he falls in line with the other men who find it un-masculine to speak openly about their feelings. He doesn’t associate expressing emotions to be masculine or feminine; it is a human quality, a necessity and a treasure. The situation is just far too delicate for him. Y/n is a fragment belonging to a rare batch of people that he trusts; the world is sometimes so cruel and unkind, and y/n is the uniqueness that makes it worthwhile. With her and y/n practically attached at the hip, Harry understands how y/n manages to stick herself in a strange combination of people. She herself views her life as similar as the next average human being struggling for survival. She is a person who shops in the sale section, dines at McDonald’s, and pays her rent late every now and then; the lavishing lifestyle is not her safe space.

Even so, she takes part in an interesting act. Her compliance to a night full of hype and hysteria, flashing cameras and mindful eyes – it is not who she is, but she portrays the role very well. She walks into the party, grinning at the other guests, though Harry has a deep instinctive feeling that she now wants nothing more than to go back home.

So damn the tequila, he says to himself, glaring at the innocent drink, but damn, the tequila resembles a craving that he has been missing. It feels so strangely smooth running down his pretty throat, and he feels it electrifying his veins. 

Another hour passes. He giggles more often than usual. People come up to him to take pictures – praising him and flaunting his name – and he sticks his wild tongue out in almost all of them. He grows affectionate and clings to his friends, but only his friends. He cannot find the person that he really wants to cuddle. He’s not even sure if she’s still at the party, but frankly, he doesn’t care. This is his night, and he wants to spend it in a hazy cloud of illusions, drowning in the purple lights and blaring music.

Harry smiles. His lips fold tightly together, his flush face exposing his current state of mind. “Not yet.” He shakes his head. He swivels his chair back to the front, calls the bartender over so that he can order him and his bestest best friend – don’t tell Mitch – a persuasive shot.

“Not for me,” Jeff declines, waving his hand horizontally in a slicing motion across his throat. “And honestly, you should consider holding back too.”

He grins up at him, dimples and all, and guides his heavy arms over Jeff’s shoulders. “Ah, you’re so caring, you little—” Harry finishes his sentence with a growl, attacking his friend’s closest cheek by taking a playful bite between his pearly teeth. “Very caring, you are. “You’re sure?”

“Yes! It’s a party, Jeffery! Go out and enjoy yourself.”

Despite his encouragement, Jeff takes a seat on the stool next to Harry and keeps him company. He stays for his friend, who he knows is a bit of an impulsive drunk, and also someone that relishes in camaraderie. It is also more challenging, Jeff says, for the pesky strangers and tag-alongs to come up to Harry when he is already in a private conversation with his manager. Therefore, the friends talk, and they laugh, and one has to keep the other from losing all of his brain cells. It is a nice pattern that ensues for half an hour until Jeff announces that he needs to use the restroom.

“I’ll be right back,” he says into Harry’s ear, two hands pat his shoulders before he is off on his quest. While he has fair intentions, Harry knows that he will not be right back. He will spend some time actually looking for the toilets, squirm through tightly packed bodies both stationary and in rhythmic motion. At an event like this, there is also surely to be a line. Then to squirm his way back – it will be some time before he returns, which means that for some time, Harry will be alone. Right now, Harry alone is a very dangerous circumstance.

His second mistake is to notice the hard, solid item in the back pocket of his trousers. It starts to bother him, especially with the seating position that he is in. He pulls the device out, and glares at how comfortably it fits in his right hand. His third mistake – oh, he certainty fears his third. He doesn’t go on now to gawk at the numbers or scroll through his feed. He taps on the search bar, thumbs hesitant for a second before typing away at the keyboard until her familiar handle appears. It has been months since he’s seen her profile, even before his visit to her apartment. Her biography is simple and sweet, her profile photo is a true depiction of who she is. Her posts are a combination of snapshots, from mirror selfies to remarkable scenery to fun nights to memes, memes, and memes. All of it is boldly her, but her most recent post captivates his attention. 

He clicks on the slightly edited picture to enlarge the two women who pose together. Taken from the waist up, the duo flashes similar seductive expressions at the camera. “Having a good time?” a loud voice shouts into ear, grips his left shoulder, and lets their hand hang from the firm crevice of his warm neck.

Harry nearly drops his phone face-down on the wet laminate surface of the bar. His heart races as he makes a quick and sly move to lock his phone, the screen turns black mid-jolt of surprise. He swerves to his right side to meet with his intruder, and discovers a pair of recognizable piercing eyes. You know there’s something there because even if you feel nothing for me, even if it’s only me and I’m an idiot to be in love with someone that doesn’t love me back, it’s still true. I’m in love with you, and that’s still something.”

With his head tilting down to confess in her ear, y/n’s eyes focus on the rolls of his neck to which a silver chain kisses and a blanket of warm skin hugs. It is so easy to fall into his words. So easy to bury herself in his embrace, to feel the electric pull of his entire being. So, so easy.

“So, tell me again,” he says, a soothing turn to the treacherous ambience that bubbles them in, away from the world outside. “Tell me that you’re not in love with me, but don’t try to tell me how I feel about you. Because it’s always been you, y/n.”

Y/n’s lips wrinkle, a prominent pout that portrays the weakness he had once wanted to see. Now that his eyes sparkle over them so clearly, he wants nothing more than to wash her fragility away. “Not always,” she mumbles, her mouth moving to the side of her face. In consequence of that forms a smile, but there is nothing humorous in the gesture. It’s sad, frightfully so, as if she sees herself as nothing but a joke. “It’s always been someone else. You know that. Even if in the back of your mind you were thinking of me, you were with someone else. You might think that everything you’re saying is true, but I was never entirely yours. I knew that from the start.”

“No, that’s…” Harry shakes his head. He makes a bold decision to reach a single hand up – the left one, with his inked cross swaying back and forth to the calming rhythm that she admires – and cups the side of her face in a graceful manner. His touch hovers over her wet skin, and it hurts to know that it is his doing. “That’s entirely different, y/n.”

“Maybe for you.” She shrugs. “But not to me. Not in my eyes.”

What can he say? It isn’t as if he can convince her that her perspective is otherwise – he has to validate these feelings. He has to understand her reasoning, or else he is right back where he had started.

“Alright.” He nods, caressing a single thumb over her cheek. He savors the moment; the scent that he inhales is intoxicatingly addictive. He doesn’t know when it will end, or when will be the last time he can breathe her in like this, so close together. “I can’t change that. I can’t change how you viewed everything, and it’s my fault that you even had to see it that way at all. I’m to blame, and I know that.”

Y/n shakes her head. “It’s not about pointing fingers, Harry.”

“I know. I know it’s not, but it’s a start.”

“A start to what?” y/n asks exasperatedly. She searches for something in him, but he’s not sure of what exactly. An answer? A defeat? A silence that cannot possibly solve any of her inquiries and fears?

“A start to whatever the hell this is,” Harry answers without a stutter in his voice. “Me figuring out how to prove to you that it has always been you, and how I fear that it always will be you. That’s not healthy, y/n, in a world of billions and only being moved by one. If I have to spend the rest of my life proving myself to you, I won’t hesitate to do it. Even if you don’t want me, which I’m sorry to say, but I’m pretty sure we’ve already found out is not the case.”

Y/n softly chuckles, and it is then he notices that her tears no longer flow. It is progress, and it has been a struggle to get here. “You won’t be able to,” she says. “I know my worth, but that doesn’t mean I don’t tear myself apart sometimes. You don’t make that any easier and the worst part is that it’s not even your fault. You can’t stop the rest of the world from loving you, so I’m sorry to say that you won’t be able to convince me of anything otherwise.”

“I beg to differ.”

“I don’t care.”

“Why can’t I just try?” he asks, and this time his other hand follows. He has her entire face in his hold, and she looks so precious standing here, her faces squishes, her pouty but kissable lips. “You say that I don’t make it easier, but you haven’t even tried to see if maybe it’s not as hard as you think.”

“Because I know myself better than anyone, Harry. Sometimes, I even know you better than you know yourself. I envision your future and how everything will turn out, and I worry over things that don’t even concern me. I live your life in ways that you haven’t even dreamed about and I understand your little catchphrases and your antics. I do it all for you, because someone has to, and I don’t know why it has to be, but it is. I do that for you, so pardon me if I already have an idea of how hellish this could turn out.”

When y/n looks up at Harry, she sees a wavering light that flickers with stardust. His universe has never looked lovelier, but it also has a strangeness to it that she is not familiar with. Her little rant ends on a negative note, so she doesn’t know why he stares at her as though she is the first existence he has ever known.

“God, I’m so in love with you,” He declares, and he doesn’t give her any time to process before he has his mouth over hers. It is inviting, to feel the shape that fits so well with his. This is the crave that he has been missing, this sudden wild flare of emotions, and though it is not perfect, it is more than enough for him.

Y/n mumbles against his lips, though he doesn’t miss the fact that she pulls him in as much he does to her. Her hand has found his waist, but her pesky lips keep mumbling, breaking apart the contact that he wishes to endure for the rest of his life. “No, this is a bad idea,” she speaks into his lips, the same hand on his waist now faintly pushing him away.

“No, it’s not,” he kisses back.

“Mm-mmm.” y/n shakes her head. Their lips pull away, and when they do, she notices the transfer of her lipstick onto his mouth. “This is,” she pauses, and lets out a laughing huff, “this is not going to work out at all.”

“Why do you keep saying that?” he asks, his hands travel down to her shoulders. He rubs against them, then slithers his way down to her upper back. It is much harder for her to escape him now. “Why can’t you allow yourself this? You daydream about the future but none of it matters because try as you might, you’ll never really know how amazing this can be.”

“It can’t be so amazing.”

“Why bloody not?”

“Because you said so yourself!” she exclaims, and he opens his mouth to retaliate, but she beats him to the mark. “You might not have said it exactly, but you definitely said it. You said that this is your life and you can’t slow down and that it’s different for you! As far as I’m concerned, that doesn’t sound so amazing. You’re in the clouds now, Harry, and you’re going to reach galaxies you’ve never even imagined. From down on the ground, it looks like you’re never going to stop, and you won’t. You can’t. Not even for the person that you’re in love with.”

Her words are fairly blunt, but Harry recalls their conversation. His single confession to her only play of a wild card, a distant memory that can properly place itself into another dimension. That night, they had not been happy. They had been foolish, going about the situation in all the wrong ways, because the silence has never been their friend. Between them, there is never an absence, never a stillness in the air. It has always been just them, the way they interact with each other, whether it is a surplus of verbal words or conversations through their looks and gestures. They had been missing that treasure on that cursed night, and neither of them were attentive enough to realize it.

Harry smiles at her. His dimple is prominent, and she has to keep herself from swooning at the close sight of it. “You don’t know,” he says, joy laces in his tone. She tilts her head in a quizzical manner: know what? she asks with her stare, the silence never prevailing. “You don’t know how everything looks like through my eyes. When I see you, and the world gets hazy, and I can’t hear or feel anything. My heart turns into something else, something I can’t explain. I don’t understand how when I’m with you, time just … stops. Everything stops for you.”

Harry pulls her in slowly, their foreheads brushing as their noses crinkle against each other. “I promise,” he whispers, nudging at her so that she can welcome her sweet lips to his. “Everything stops for you,” he repeats, and connects their lips for a third time, and each one holds something different, something unexplainably special. He wants to say more, to further prove himself, and prove how well their love can be. He can’t though, because her lips press against his, her hands wrap around him, and she lets herself fall in love with everything he is and everything he has to give.

After a short lip-locking moment – where not much privacy ensues, and he tries not to mind whatever pictures surface the next morning – their movements become a little sloppier, and Harry has the devilish urge to bite on her swollen lip. He pulls at it between his cheeky grin, which gets a grimacing smile out of her as they separate. He can’t control the flutter of laughter that escapes him, attacking her with a chaste kiss on her cheek before whispering in her ear. “Hey, if you’re up for it, we can try out that kink of yours now.”

“Ugh.” Y/n rolls her eyes, then reaches up to twist his nipple through his button-up. “Such a gentleman you are.”

“Ow!” he yelps, giggling as he palms at the sensitive area. “You didn’t tell me that was part of it, cheeky lovie!”
